results.name: Decimal expansion of Pi^2/4.
link: Muniru A Asiru, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..2000
Ben Hambrecht and Grant Sanderson, The stunning geometry behind this surprising equation, 3Blue1Brown video (2018).
Josef Hofbauer, A simple proof of 1 + 1/2^2 + 1/3^2 + ... = Pi^2/6 and related identities, The American Mathematical Monthly 109:2 (2002), pp. 196-200.
T. Piezas III, Golden ratio and nested radicals
Johan Wästlund, Summing inverse squares by euclidean geometry
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Definite Integral
formula: Equals integral(x=0..1) log((1+x)/(1-x))/x dx. - _Jean-François Alcover_, May 13 2013
Equals integral_{x=0..infinity} K_0(x)^2 dx, where K_0 is a modified Bessel function (see Gradstein-Ryshik 6.576.4). - _R. J. Mathar_, Oct 09 2015
Equals A003881 * A000796. - _R. J. Mathar_, Oct 09 2015
Pi^2/4 = Integral_{x = 0..inf} x/sinh(x) dx. More generally, Pi^2/4 = 2*(1 + 1/3^2 + ... + 1/(2*n-1)^2) + Integral_{x = 0..inf} exp(-2*n*x)*x/sinh(x). - _Peter Bala_, Nov 05 2019
Equals Integral_{x=0..oo} log(x)/(x^2 - 1) dx. - _Amiram Eldar_, Aug 12 2020
results.author: _Eric W. Weisstein_, Jan 13 2004
